awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in China
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds Melinda A. Yang of University of California Berkeley to conduct a research project in Biological Sciences during the summer of 2013 at the Ancient DNA Laboratory of Jilin University in Changchun, Jilin Province, China.  The project title is "Determining the Genetic Relationship among Early Bronze Age Peoples in the Central Plains of China." The host scientist is Professor Hui Zhou.

This study applies a population genetic approach to analyze ancient population structure in geographically restricted regions and explore changes through time from ancient populations to the present day. The research focuses on human populations of the Shang (~1600-1027 BC) and Zhou (1027-771 BC) dynasties from the Central Plains of Early Bronze Age China. It compares ancient genetic material from Shang and Zhou bone specimens to each other and to modern East Asian samples to test the hypotheses that the Shang and Zhou are biologically distinct and that these ancient populations fall within the genetic diversity of present day East Asians.  Ancient DNA is being extracted at Jilin University. 

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language.   These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.  Furthermore, the EAPSI fellowship will strengthen academic ties between UC Berkeley, the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, and Jilin University. The research conducted under the fellowship is directly relevant to the history of China. The research will be communicated to Chinese populations near Jilin University and in the Bay Area of the United States. The results will be developed into a lesson to for grade K-5 students in the Bay Area Scientists in School program, of which the Fellow is an active member. The research will also be shared with scientists in archaeology and biology at conferences such as the International Symposium of Biomolecular Archaeology and the Society for Molecular Biology and Evolution.

por.por_cntn:
The research project that was begun during the NSF East Asia Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) 2013 in China was on the genetic relationship between Early Bronze Age human populations in China to each other and present day East Asians. The Early Bronze Age of China refers to the period of the first three dynasties of China, the Xia, the Shang, and the Zhou. In particular, I was studying the Shang to Zhou transition, which is detailed in history as a conquest of the Shang by the Zhou people around 1050 BC. Historical records describe a political distinction between the Shang and Zhou, and archaeological research shows many different patterns in the material remains between sites believed to belong to the Zhou and the Shang. These cultural differences suggest a cultural transition, but it is less clear whether a biological transition occurred as well. Thus, this project was conceived to begin studying the biological nature of the transition from the Shang to the Zhou. My goal over the summer was to acquire experience in an ancient DNA (aDNA) wet lab, obtain samples from the Shang and Zhou Dynasties from collaborators in the field of archaeology, and begin testing for aDNA in the samples. My results show that some aDNA is present in samples I obtained this summer, and further work is needed to successfully sequence more aDNA for comprehensive population genetic analyses.

                The broader impact of this study and participating in the EAPSI was great. I established strong relationships with several Chinese researchers in the fields of genetics and archaeology. Furthermore, these strong contacts allowed me to regularly discuss academia in China and the United States with graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in the lab in which I was hosted, giving greater insight into how our two communities function, which hopefully will lead to better collaborations in the future. I shared my research at the Young Scientists’ Forum in Beijing in August, and back at UC Berkeley with fellow researchers. Furthermore, I learned a great deal by participating in the wet lab at Jilin University, where I was hosted by Professor Hui Zhou, who is a leading expert on genetic relationships in ancient Chinese populations. Trained as a computational geneticist, I gained invaluable wet lab skills that will help my future research. This opportunity has afforded me experiences that have already greatly improved my ability to conduct research. My growing international collaborations, my increased skill set, and my experience working in a different environment all have improved my ability to conduct this research. My preliminary results from this summer has been used to apply for further funding to answer the question of the biological nature of the Shang to Zhou transition.
